A dictionary of values used during the checking process to perform. See Spell Checking Option Dictionary Keys for the supported values.
The type of checking to be performed, passed by-reference. The possible constants are listed in
and can be combined using the C bit-wise
operator to perform multiple checks at the same time.
You can change this parameter to alter the types of checking to be performed.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
An interface to the Cocoa spell-checking service.
The constants are optional keys that can be used in the options dictionary parameter of the
, and
methods.
Requests unified text checking for the given range of the given string.
Provides a menu containing contextual menu items suitable for certain kinds of detected results.
Requests that the string be checked in the background.
A view that draws text and handles user interactions with that text.
Check and replace the text in the range using the specified checking types and options.
A set of optional methods that text view delegates can use to manage selection, set text attributes, work with the spell checker, and more.
Invoked to allow the delegate to modify the text checking results after checking has occurred.
Sent when the spelling state is changed.
Invoked to allow the delegate to modify the text checking process before it occurs.

Defines the types of checking that are available. These values can be combined using the C-bitwise OR operator. The system supports its own internal types, and the user can extend those types by subclassing `NSTextCheckingResult` and adding their own custom types.
A Swift-only concrete structure that backs the range type alias.

Defines the types of checking that are available. These values can be combined using the C-bitwise OR operator. The system supports its own internal types, and the user can extend those types by subclassing `NSTextCheckingResult` and adding their own custom types.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
